data.title: Afterglow (1997)
data.meta_description: A handyman with marital problems meets a housewife with the same.
data.text:
Is there a better use of music in a film than Tom Waits' Somewhere cover at the end of this film? Maybe What'd I Say in Cosmic Ray for pure effect... but there is no more appropriate use of music I can think of, both because Waits' raspy voice sounds like Nick Nolte's, and because Waits' mannered, overtly stylized performance style gives way to such a torrent of emotion in this song. To appreciate the song requires one to look beyond his idiosyncrasies as a vocalist and fully accept what he is doing as a genuine expression of real feeling. This is much like what Rudolph expects us to do with his films and his characters; think about the moment…

sorry but fuck this.

look at that poster. read that synopsis.

you'd assume an underwatched middling romcom? even Amazon says that its a "stylish dramedy". huge mistake.

this film is sheer anti-sex nightmare. its fucking Crash (1996) for your mum and dad. Its one of those films that makes you feel like theres another, new organ inside your body liquefying into blackness and feeding your brain gangrenous pieces of itself.

this film is about sexual hurt, infidelities complex knowledges, marital mistakes made raw, its about the sheer vicious directionless pain of loss and sex's completely temporary high to trick ourselves into feeling that our present, thanks to our past, is absolutely fine, despite the wallpaper peeling and the damp entering…

Julie Christie has the kind of face you find on the covers of romance novels, and surely one of the reasons she was cast in "Dr. Zhivago" was that she would look so good on the poster. She projects the wounded perfection of a great beauty who has had the wrong sort of luck. In "Afterglow," only her third role in the 1990s, Alan Rudolph has given her the sort of character she knows inside out: bemused, sad, needful, mysterious. - Ebert

Nick Nolte, Jonny Lee Miller, and Lara Flynn Boyle fit their roles, but this role fits Christie perfectly. It feels written for her. I wish there was another movie with this same cast in this same universe, but…
